G.L. c. 212, \u00a7 4.proposition: This Court has subject matter jurisdiction over this action pursuant to G.L. c. 212, § 4, because the amount in controversy exceeds $25,000, exclusive of interest and costs.

G.L. c. 223, \u00a7\u00a7 1 and 2.proposition: Venue is proper in Hampden County under G.L. c. 223, §§ 1 and 2, because the parties reside in Hampden County and the events and damages giving rise to this action occurred at 123 Maple Street in Springfield, Hampden County, Massachusetts.

G.L. c. 90, \u00a7 7.proposition: Although the vehicle remained mechanically operable, the cracked windshield rendered the vehicle unsafe and likely unlawful to operate, and it would not pass a Massachusetts vehicle inspection in that condition.

Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693 (1973).proposition: Under Massachusetts law, a person who creates or maintains a condition on property owes a duty to exercise reasonable care to avoid subjecting others lawfully on or near the premises to an unreasonable risk of harm. See *Mounsey v. Ellard*, 363 Mass. 693 (1973) (establishing general duty of reasonable care to all lawful visitors).
Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693 (1973).support_reasoning: The quoted text is only a concurrence and does not itself articulate the general duty rule, but it confirms that the majority opinion has abandoned the traditional licensee/invitee distinction and moved toward a broader, status‑independent negligence standard. In Massachusetts, Mounsey is widely recognized as establishing a general duty of reasonable care owed by occupiers to all lawful entrants; Kaplan, J.’s concurrence criticizes any residual distinction for trespassers, reinforcing that the core reasoning extends a duty to lawful visitors. However, the precise formulation in the proposition is drawn from the majority, not from this specific excerpt.
Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693 (1973).relevant_excerpt: "The court holds that the measure of responsibility of an occupier should no longer depend on whether the injured person is characterized as a ‘licensee’ rather than an ‘invitee,’ or vice versa; the question is to turn on other, more vital factors. … The very effort at dry classification and differentiation puts the emphasis at the wrong places. Thus it is awkward to leave the suggestion that the basic reasoning of the court’s opinion may stop short of so called trespassers."

Jupin v. Kask, 447 Mass. 141, 146 (2006).proposition: A plaintiff asserting negligence in Massachusetts must show: (1) a legal duty owed by the defendant to the plaintiff; (2) a breach of that duty; (3) causation (both cause in fact and proximate cause); and (4) actual damages. See *Jupin v. Kask*, 447 Mass. 141, 146 (2006); *Glidden v. Maglio*, 430 Mass. 694, 696 (2000).
Jupin v. Kask, 447 Mass. 141, 146 (2006).support_reasoning: The Jupin opinion does set out the elements of negligence, but it frames them as: duty of reasonable care, breach of that duty, resulting damage, and a causal relation between the breach and the damage. It does not expressly distinguish between cause in fact and proximate cause, nor does it enumerate four elements in the precise (1)-(4) structure stated in the proposition. Thus, while it generally supports the basic negligence-elements idea, it does not specifically support the more detailed formulation including both factual and proximate causation as separate components.
Jupin v. Kask, 447 Mass. 141, 146 (2006).relevant_excerpt: "To prevail on a negligence claim, a plaintiff must prove that the defendant owed the plaintiff a duty of reasonable care, that the defendant breached this duty, that damage resulted, and that there was a causal relation between the breach of the duty and the damage."

Glidden v. Maglio, 430 Mass. 694, 696 (2.proposition: A plaintiff asserting negligence in Massachusetts must show: (1) a legal duty owed by the defendant to the plaintiff; (2) a breach of that duty; (3) causation (both cause in fact and proximate cause); and (4) actual damages. See *Jupin v. Kask*, 447 Mass. 141, 146 (2006); *Glidden v. Maglio*, 430 Mass. 694, 696 (2000).
Glidden v. Maglio, 430 Mass. 694, 696 (2.support_reasoning: The Glidden opinion does not set out the full four-element negligence test including both cause in fact and proximate cause. It describes the plaintiff’s burden more generally as proving breach of duty, actual loss, and that the defendant’s negligence caused the loss, and it cites the Restatement and a tort treatise rather than articulating the specific four-part formulation. Thus, Glidden is about failure of proof on causation, but it is not clear authority for the precise, element-by-element proposition stated.
Glidden v. Maglio, 430 Mass. 694, 696 (2.relevant_excerpt: With respect to each such claim, the plaintiffs bear the burden of proving that the defendant committed a breach of the duty to use reasonable care, that the plaintiffs suffered actual loss, and that the defendant’s negligence caused their loss. See Restatement (Second) of Torts § 281 (1965); J.R. Nolan & L.J. Sartorio, Tort Law § 204 (2d ed. 1989). Causation is an essential element of that proof.

Poskus v. Lombardo\u2019s of Randolph, I.raw_text: Poskus v. Lombardo’s of Randolph, Inc., 423 Mass. 637, 639–40 (1996)
Poskus v. Lombardo\u2019s of Randolph, I.proposition: Foreseeability of harm is a central component of duty and proximate cause in Massachusetts negligence law. See *Poskus v. Lombardo’s of Randolph, Inc.*, 423 Mass. 637, 639–40 (1996); *Afarian v. Mass. Elec. Co.*, 449 Mass. 257, 262–63 (2007).
Poskus v. Lombardo\u2019s of Randolph, I.case_name: Poskus v. Lombardo's of Randolph, Inc.
Poskus v. Lombardo\u2019s of Randolph, I.support_reasoning: The concurrence explicitly frames the negligence question in terms of whether the plaintiff’s injuries were within the “reasonably foreseeable risk of harm” created by the defendant’s negligence, which is the foreseeability formulation of duty/proximate cause. Although this is a concurring opinion and not the majority, it still reflects that Massachusetts negligence analysis centrally turns on foreseeability of harm. Without the full majority text, support is inferred but not perfectly clear, so confidence is medium rather than high.
Poskus v. Lombardo\u2019s of Randolph, I.relevant_excerpt: “I concur in the view that ‘[t]he facts would not warrant a jury’s finding that the plaintiff[’]s injuries were within the reasonably foreseeable risk of harm created by Lombardo’s negligence.’ Ante at 640-641.”

Afarian v. Mass. Elec. Co., 449 Mass. 25.raw_text: Afarian v. Mass. Elec. Co., 449 Mass. 257, 262–63 (2007)
Afarian v. Mass. Elec. Co., 449 Mass. 25.proposition: Foreseeability of harm is a central component of duty and proximate cause in Massachusetts negligence law. See *Poskus v. Lombardo’s of Randolph, Inc.*, 423 Mass. 637, 639–40 (1996); *Afarian v. Mass. Elec. Co.*, 449 Mass. 257, 262–63 (2007).
Afarian v. Mass. Elec. Co., 449 Mass. 25.support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly frames duty in terms of reasonable foreseeability and repeatedly describes foreseeability of harm as a prerequisite to, and central limiter on, tort duty. It quotes and adopts formulations that a defendant owes a duty to all persons foreseeably endangered by their conduct and that the existence of a tort duty is governed by a test of the reasonable foreseeability of harm. The court then applies that foreseeability analysis to determine that no duty exists in the specific context of drunk drivers colliding with utility poles.
Afarian v. Mass. Elec. Co., 449 Mass. 25.relevant_excerpt: “We have recognized that ‘[a]s a general principle of tort law, every actor has a duty to exercise reasonable care to avoid physical harm to others.’ … A precondition to this duty is, of course, that the risk of harm to another be recognizable or foreseeable to the actor… Consequently, with some important exceptions, ‘a defendant owes a duty of care to all persons who are foreseeably endangered by his conduct, with respect to all risks which make the conduct unreasonably dangerous.’ … ‘To the extent that a legal standard does exist for determining the existence of a tort duty … , it is a test of the “reasonable foreseeability” of the harm.’”

Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Aut.raw_text: Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Auth., 363 Mass. 165, 167–68 (1973)
Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Aut.proposition: A defendant who has actual knowledge of a hazardous condition, particularly after being expressly warned, and fails to correct it or warn of it can be found negligent for resulting harm. See *Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Auth.*, 363 Mass. 165, 167–68 (1973) (duty to remedy known dangers); *Papadopoulos v. Target Corp.*, 457 Mass. 368, 379 (2010) (duty of reasonable care regarding foreseeable hazards).
Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Aut.case_name: Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transportation Authority
Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Aut.support_reasoning: The case certainly recites the general premises-liability duty to use due care to keep premises reasonably safe or warn of dangers that are known or should be known, but the opinion’s analysis and holding are about whether the plaintiff proved the *time element*—i.e., constructive notice of a foreign substance through circumstantial evidence. There is no discussion of a defendant having actual knowledge after being expressly warned and then failing to remedy or warn; indeed, Oliveri ends with judgment for the defendant. Thus, it does not substantively support the more specific proposition about actual knowledge following an express warning leading to negligence, though it can be cited more narrowly for the general duty to remedy or warn of known dangers.
Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Aut.relevant_excerpt: “The obligation of one who controls business premises is to use due care to keep the premises provided for the use of its patrons in a reasonably safe condition, or at least to warn them of any dangers that might arise from such use, which are not likely to be known to them, and of which the defendant knows or ought to know. … Where a foreign substance on a floor or stairway causes the business visitor to fall and sustain injuries, he may prove the negligence of the defendant by proof that the defendant or his servant caused the substance to be there, or he may show that the defendant or his servants had actual knowledge of the existence of the foreign substance.”

Papadopoulos v. Target Corp., 457 Mass..proposition: A defendant who has actual knowledge of a hazardous condition, particularly after being expressly warned, and fails to correct it or warn of it can be found negligent for resulting harm. See *Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Auth.*, 363 Mass. 165, 167–68 (1973) (duty to remedy known dangers); *Papadopoulos v. Target Corp.*, 457 Mass. 368, 379 (2010) (duty of reasonable care regarding foreseeable hazards).
Papadopoulos v. Target Corp., 457 Mass..support_reasoning: Papadopoulos is not about express warnings to the defendant, but it clearly affirms the broader principle that a landowner who knows or should know of a hazardous condition (including snow and ice) owes a duty of reasonable care to protect lawful visitors, which encompasses correcting the condition or otherwise protecting against it. The opinion abolishes the natural/unnatural accumulation distinction and squarely states that if a property owner knows or reasonably should know of a dangerous condition, it must make reasonable efforts to protect visitors, aligning with the cited proposition’s general negligence principle.
Papadopoulos v. Target Corp., 457 Mass..relevant_excerpt: If a property owner knows or reasonably should know of a dangerous condition on its property, whether arising from an accumulation of snow or ice, or rust on a railing, or a discarded banana peel, the property owner owes a duty to lawful visitors to make reasonable efforts to protect lawful visitors against the danger. See Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, 448 Mass. 780, 782-784 (2007); Restatement (Second) of Torts § 343 (1965).

Larkin v. Ralph O. Porter, Inc., 405 Mas.raw_text: Larkin v. Ralph O. Porter, Inc., 405 Mass. 179, 183 (1989)
Larkin v. Ralph O. Porter, Inc., 405 Mas.proposition: One who controls property or instrumentalities on it owes reasonable care to prevent them from causing foreseeable damage to others, including neighboring property. See *Larkin v. Ralph O. Porter, Inc.*, 405 Mass. 179, 183 (1989) (duty based on control of property and foreseeability); *Dos Santos v. Coleta*, 465 Mass. 148, 154–56 (2013) (duty regarding dangerous instrumentalities and conditions).
Larkin v. Ralph O. Porter, Inc., 405 Mas.case_name: Larkin v. RALPH O. PORTER, INC. CEBCO CORP.
Larkin v. Ralph O. Porter, Inc., 405 Mas.support_reasoning: The opinion is about whether a general contractor can obtain indemnification from a subcontractor/employer notwithstanding the workers’ compensation exclusivity provisions. It analyzes implied contractual indemnity and vicarious liability, not a tort duty arising from control of property or instrumentalities or duties owed to neighboring property. The court does not discuss a general duty of care based on control of property or foreseeable harm, so it does not support the cited negligence proposition.
Larkin v. Ralph O. Porter, Inc., 405 Mas.relevant_excerpt: “This right to indemnity is limited to those cases in which the would-be indemnitee is held derivatively or vicariously liable for the wrongful act of another. … In Vertentes v. Barletta Co., 392 Mass. 165 (1984), we specifically held that a general contractor could not be held vicariously liable to the employee of its subcontractor when that employee is injured because of an act or omission of the subcontractor.”

Dos Santos v. Coleta, 465 Mass. 148, 154.proposition: One who controls property or instrumentalities on it owes reasonable care to prevent them from causing foreseeable damage to others, including neighboring property. See *Larkin v. Ralph O. Porter, Inc.*, 405 Mass. 179, 183 (1989) (duty based on control of property and foreseeability); *Dos Santos v. Coleta*, 465 Mass. 148, 154–56 (2013) (duty regarding dangerous instrumentalities and conditions).
Dos Santos v. Coleta, 465 Mass. 148, 154.support_reasoning: The opinion directly discusses a landowner/possessor’s duty of reasonable care regarding dangerous conditions and instrumentalities on the land, including the duty to remedy an open and obvious danger where harm is nonetheless foreseeable. It holds that the defendants who created and maintained the trampoline–pool configuration owed a duty to remedy that dangerous condition because they could and should have anticipated injury despite its obviousness. While the facts involve an on‑premises entrant rather than a neighboring property owner, the case clearly supports the general control/foreseeability-based duty regarding dangerous conditions and instrumentalities on property.
Dos Santos v. Coleta, 465 Mass. 148, 154.relevant_excerpt: “An owner or possessor of land owes a common-law duty of reasonable care to all persons lawfully on the premises. … This duty includes an obligation to maintain the ‘property in a reasonably safe condition in view of all the circumstances, including the likelihood of injury to others, the seriousness of the injury, and the burden of avoiding the risk.’ … [A] landowner… ‘is not relieved from remedying an open and obvious danger where [the landowner] “can and should anticipate that the dangerous condition will cause physical harm … notwithstanding its known or obvious danger.”’ … On these facts, a jury were entitled to conclude that the defendants owed a duty of care — specifically a duty to remedy — despite the open and obvious nature of the danger.”

LeBlanc v. Logan Hilton Joint Venture, 4.raw_text: LeBlanc v. Logan Hilton Joint Venture, 463 Mass. 316, 325 (2012)
LeBlanc v. Logan Hilton Joint Venture, 4.proposition: A defendant may be liable in negligence where unsecured objects or structures, left in an unsafe condition, foreseeably fall or are displaced by weather, causing injury or damage. See e.g., *Jupin v. Kask*, 447 Mass. at 149–50 (discussing duty regarding foreseeable misuse or movement of dangerous items); *LeBlanc v. Logan Hilton Joint Venture*, 463 Mass. 316, 325 (2012) (duty to guard against reasonably foreseeable events based on known conditions).
LeBlanc v. Logan Hilton Joint Venture, 4.case_name: LeBlanc v. Logan Hilton Joint Venture
LeBlanc v. Logan Hilton Joint Venture, 4.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns an architect/engineer’s duty, arising from a contract, to report known safety-related deficiencies (missing electrical warning signage) to the owner and the resulting professional negligence exposure. It does not discuss unsecured objects or structures being displaced by weather, nor liability for injuries caused by such movement. The court’s references to foreseeable safety risks are tied to professional duties in construction and electrical system design/monitoring, not to weather-related displacement of objects, so using this case for that specific proposition is inaccurate.
LeBlanc v. Logan Hilton Joint Venture, 4.relevant_excerpt: “Because the evidence in the summary judgment record is sufficient to support a finding that LeBlanc’s death was caused by the professional negligence of the Design Team based on their failure to report known deficiencies to Hilton that posed a serious safety risk to anyone who operated the switchgear, the judge erred in granting summary judgment to the Design Team on the cross claims for contribution brought by Hilton and Broadway.”

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 85.proposition: Under G.L. c. 231, § 85, Massachusetts follows a comparative negligence regime, but Plaintiff was not negligent and did not contribute to the hazard created by Defendant.

Hopkins v. Medeiros, 48 Mass. App. Ct. 6.raw_text: Hopkins v. Medeiros, 48 Mass. App. Ct. 600, 613–14 (2000)
Hopkins v. Medeiros, 48 Mass. App. Ct. 6.proposition: Damage to property and loss-of-use damages are recoverable as part of negligence damages in Massachusetts when proximately caused by the defendant’s breach of duty. See *Hopkins v. Medeiros*, 48 Mass. App. Ct. 600, 613–14 (2000) (recognizing compensation for reasonably foreseeable consequential damages); see also *Guaranty-First Trust Co. v. Textron, Inc.*, 416 Mass. 332, 336–37 (1993).
Hopkins v. Medeiros, 48 Mass. App. Ct. 6.support_reasoning: The opinion in Hopkins v. Medeiros addresses duty, the rescue doctrine, and the firefighter’s rule; it does not discuss the measure or categories of recoverable negligence damages such as property damage or loss-of-use. There is no analysis or recognition in this excerpt that ‘reasonably foreseeable consequential damages’—including damage to property and loss-of-use—are compensable in negligence. The case therefore does not provide authority for the specific damages proposition cited.
Hopkins v. Medeiros, 48 Mass. App. Ct. 6.relevant_excerpt: Because the opinion is focused on duty, rescue doctrine, and the firefighter’s rule, and does not meaningfully discuss types or scope of recoverable damages, there is no passage that directly supports the stated proposition about property and loss-of-use damages.

Guaranty-First Trust Co. v. Textron, Inc.raw_text: Guaranty-First Trust Co. v. Textron, Inc., 416 Mass. 332, 336–37 (1993)
Guaranty-First Trust Co. v. Textron, Inc.proposition: Damage to property and loss-of-use damages are recoverable as part of negligence damages in Massachusetts when proximately caused by the defendant’s breach of duty. See *Hopkins v. Medeiros*, 48 Mass. App. Ct. 600, 613–14 (2000) (recognizing compensation for reasonably foreseeable consequential damages); see also *Guaranty-First Trust Co. v. Textron, Inc.*, 416 Mass. 332, 336–37 (1993).
Guaranty-First Trust Co. v. Textron, Inc.case_name: Guaranty-First Trust Co. v. Textron, Inc.
Guaranty-First Trust Co. v. Textron, Inc.support_reasoning: The opinion squarely addresses what elements of damages are available for property damage and expressly states that, at common law, a party suffering property damage may also recover for loss of use, including lost rent, as part of the remedy so long as it is tied to the period reasonably necessary to repair the damage. Although the case arises under G.L. c. 21E, the court explicitly incorporates and applies the common-law measure of damages in negligence/property damage cases, confirming that property damage and loss-of-use damages are recoverable when proximately caused by the defendant’s conduct. The proposition is thus accurately supported, with the caveat that such loss-of-use damages are limited to the reasonable repair period.
Guaranty-First Trust Co. v. Textron, Inc.relevant_excerpt: “At common law, ‘[t]he general rule for measuring property damage is diminution in market value.’ … A party suffering property damage may also recover for loss of use. … Lost rent is therefore an appropriate part of the remedy for damage to real property to the extent it represents diminution in market value or loss of use. … [W]here damage to real property is not permanent, the measure of recovery is the reasonable expense of repairing the injury plus the intervening loss of rental value for the period reasonably needed to repair the injury.”

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 6B.proposition: Plaintiff may recover interest on any judgment under G.L. c. 231, § 6B (prejudgment interest in tort actions) and costs pursuant to G.L. c. 261, §§ 1 et seq.

G.L. c. 261, \u00a7\u00a7 1 et seq..proposition: Plaintiff may recover interest on any judgment under G.L. c. 231, § 6B (prejudgment interest in tort actions) and costs pursuant to G.L. c. 261, §§ 1 et seq.
